cs3500.hw01.duration

Class HmsDuration

  • java.lang.Object
    • cs3500.hw01.duration.HmsDuration
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Duration, java.lang.Comparable<Duration>

    public final class HmsDuration
extends java.lang.Object
    Durations represented as hours, minutes, and seconds.

      • asHms

        public java.lang.String asHms()
        Description copied from interface: Duration
        Formats this duration in the form H:MM:SS where the hours and minutes are both zero-padded to two digits, but the hours are not. The duration should be in canonical form, meaning that both the minutes and the seconds are less than 60.
        Returns:
        this duration formatted in hours, minutes, and seconds

      • format

        public java.lang.String format(java.lang.String template)
        Description copied from interface: Duration
        Formats a duration as a string by substituting for format specifiers in the template.

        The template is a string that may contain both fixed text and some number of format specifiers, which are special two-character codes starting with a % character. This method returns a string that is like the template string, with the fixed text copied unchanged and the format specifiers replaced by textual representations of the indicated values for this duration.

        More precisely, a template is a non-null sequence of uninterpreted characters and two-character format specifiers. An uninterpreted character may be any character but '%'. A format specifier may be any of the two-character codes defined in the table below, and nothing else. The result string is the concatenation of the meanings of each of the elements of the template sequence, where the meaning of an uninterpreted character is itself, and the meaning of a format specifier is a string as defined in the table below.

        The above implies that in cases where two format specifiers appear to overlap (e.g., "%%t"), the left-most specifier takes precedence (so the result in this case would be "%t"). Alternatively, we could say that the format specifiers are interpreted from left to right, and the result of converting a specifier is never interpreted a second time.

        A template is malformed if it doesn't meet the definition of template above. Another way to think of this is that in a well-formed template, every '%' character is followed by one of the eight characters that follow % in the table below, except when it is the following character for another %.

        Format Specifier Meaning
        %tthe whole duration in seconds
        %hthe hours component of the decomposed duration
        %Hthe hours component of the decomposed duration, padded to 2 digits with leading zeros (e.g., 05 or 11)
        %mthe minutes component of the decomposed duration
        %Mthe minutes component of the decomposed duration, padded to 2 digits with leading zeros (e.g., 05 or 56)
        %sthe seconds component of the decomposed duration
        %Sthe seconds component of the decomposed duration, padded to 2 digits with leading zeros (e.g., 05 or 56)
        %%a literal percent sign (%)
        Format specifiers
        Parameters:
        template - the template
        Returns:
        the formatted string
